10/16/11 UPDATE:  The Northern Presis now have snow at about 4800 feet.  I will be requiring microspikes and appropriate winter clothing on this hike.

-------------------------

I've been hitting some of the other, non-AMC 4,000+ foot prominences and features in the Northern Presis for a while. These mountains are a playground for explorers! 

This will not be your traditional peakbagging climb.  There are much more direct ways to bag the peaks that we will pass and bagging Adams is not the ultimate goal.  While this hike will NOT be leisurely (due to the distance and difficulty), you should be willing to take some time to explore a little.  Just getting from Point A to Point B is not the Point!

We will ascend Adams via the Short Line trail to the King Ravine Trail.  Along the King Ravine trail is Mossy Falls and the Subway, a series of boulders that forms a .1 mile under/over "caving" or bouldering experience.  

From the end of the Subway, we will take the to the Great Gully Trail.  The Great Gully Trail is VERY DIFFICULT and steep as it climbs the headwall to King Ravine.  It not only requires some rock scrambling, but there is at last one point where there is some tricky footing and steep drop.  We will NOT do this climb if it is wet.  

After ascending Adams, we will take the Gulfside Trail, stopping to scramble up Adams 5 (a subsummit and 4000+ foot prominence) before heading down the mountain via Grey Knob to the Hincks Trail to the Randolph Path and back to the Short Line trail.   

We are at peak foliage!

 

Without having done this hike, I can't tell precisely how long it will take - I estimate this as an 12 hour hike , based on book time.  I'm hoping to do this a little more quickly to beat the dark.  Adams is one of the high peaks in the Whites and on the list of NH/White Mountain 48 4,000 footers.

 

Because of the difficulty of this hike and the need for careful attention to footing, I'm limiting this hike to a small group.

-------------------------

Be prepared for cool, cold and potentially poor weather conditions. DO NOT WEAR COTTON OR DENIM. If you have questions about how to prepare or how to dress, ask them in advance.  Come prepared to stay dry!!

Answers to FAQs

  • This IS NOT a traverse, so we will NOT need to carpool to another location.
  • We will meet in the Appalachia Parking Lot on Route 2 
  • Sunset will be at  about 6:17 pm.
  • This hike will be VERY EXPOSED.  Come prepared for sun, rain and cold exposure.
  • We will pass Grey Knob and possibly the Perch (RMC Huts) on this climb.  We will NOT pass any AMC huts.
  • Bring enough water.  While there ARE sources on this trail (Cold Brook, Mossy Falls), they are non-potable so your water will have to be treated.
  • Headlamps are required.  I do not plan to come out in the dark, but this is a long hike and one of the tougher mountains, so I want hikers to be prepared.  The last two hikes I did in the Northern Presis came out in the dark.  Always be prepared to come out in the dark if necessary.
  • We will START AND FINISH TOGETHER. If you cannot hold your speed down to match that of the group (if necessary), this is not the hike for you.   I require participants to wait at trail junctions, major water crossings and summits so that the group can exchange information and reset their pace.
  • I am NOT a speedy hiker, but I do keep a steady pace.  I'm doing about book time these days.
  • If the conditions are prohibitive, I have no qualms about turning around. The mountain will be there another day.  I would like you to be around for another day too.
  • My hikes area always dog friendly, but please know the limits and abilities of your dog & bring plenty of water.  The Northern Presis can be very hard on a dog's feet.  I do NOT recommend King Ravine for dogs - there is just too much rock scrambling/bouldering.  I will NOT have my dogs with me - and I bring them almost everywhere.  That said, only you know the limits and capabilities of your dogs.
  • I will watch the weather carefully and post weather updates during the week leading up to the hike. I rely on NOAA and MWObs for my forecasts.
  • I will provide attendees with my cell phone number in advance of the hike.

Most of the payoff comes in the form of great views & enjoying the outdoors.  If the weather looks like it will be miserable, I will reschedule, possibly to Sunday if it looks clearer.  Please plan accordingly.

RSVP Questions are NOT optional - If you do not provide me with a phone number to try and contact you on the morning of the hike (if necessary), we will NOT wait for you at the trailhead.

Book time is hard to estimate for this one.  Book time as listed below does not take into account the ascent of Adams 5 or stopping at any of the mentioned features.   Plan on it taking about AT LEAST this long & possibly a little more since we intend to spend some time at the true summit.  Last week we did a similar ascent of 4 summits on Adams and still made 1 hour under book time, even with several stops.

I AM NOT TRAINED TO BE A GUIDE, NOR HAVE I RECEIVED TRAINING OR INSTRUCTION IN HIKING SAFETY. WHILE I TRY TO HEAD OFF SOME OF THE PROBLEMS I HAVE SEEN (OR EXPERIENCED OR EVEN CAUSED) IN THE PAST, MY UNDERSTANDING IS THAT YOU WILL TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR YOUR OWN SAFETY. IF MY DISAPPEARANCE DURING THIS TRIP WOULD CAUSE YOU MORE THAN ANNOYANCE AND INCONVENIENCE, THIS IS NOT THE TRIP FOR YOU. THERE ARE ALWAYS RISKS IN HIKING IN THE MOUNTAINS. IF YOU ARE NOT CONFIDENT THAT YOU UNDERSTAND THE RISKS, PLEASE DO NOT SIGN UP (or change your RSVP to no). WHILE I HAVE CLIMBED THIS PEAK BEFORE, I HAVE DONE ALL MY RESEARCH VIA GUIDEBOOKS, INTERNET AND ADVICE FROM OTHER HIKERS, SO IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOME INFORMATION IS NOT ACCURATE. I AM PERFECTLY CAPABLE OF MAKING STUPID OR MINDLESS MISTAKES, SO PLEASE DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH AND COME PREPARED WITH APPROPRIATE KNOWLEDGE, EQUIPMENT AND JUDGMENT.
